titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Mr: Maury called on me this morning. Going to Liverpool. Wrote with industry, to send by him this evening. Sent accordingly.

Ordinary day. Rise between 8 and 9. Breakfast alone. Pass the principal part of the morning in writing Letters. Walk.— Dine at 5. alone, or go into company.— When alone pass the evening in writing, or go to the play. When in company seldom return till ten or eleven then read a few pages, and retire after midnight.

2. Taking my walk, went to Lackington’s shop. purchased some books. Rain as I return’d. Dined at the Piazza Coffee-house, Covent Garden. Marshall & Cutting the frenchmen, not so well supported. Mr: Gilpin a very intelligent man; but perhaps too much Englishman. Marshall said, that if Mr: Randolph did not take a bribe himself, but only proposed to Fauchet to bribe others, it was a simple indiscretion: only an imprudence. Gilpin said that the peasantry in England, were happier and lived better than the same sort of people in America. New England excepted Church said he must go to America, as he could not afford to live here.— Came away finally with Frazier & Clarke. Visit in the forenoon from Mr: Copley.

3. Walk in Hyde-Park, in the forenoon. Made out list of books for Frazier. Opinion for Mr: Copley. Evening at his house. Met there a Mr: Danforth, brother to Dr: Danforth—refugee as I suppose, and having that species of aversion to America, which appears or breaks through in the conduct of every man I have met of this description.— Reading on my return home. The life of Lackington the bookseller. It is not so good a thing as I expected.

4. Frazier Breakfasted with me. We afterwards went to see the Panorama, in Leicester fields. There are two views. one of London. the other of Lord Howe’s fleet on the 1st: of June. The effect of these views, is very striking, the paintings being placed in a circular position. the spot from which they are seen is the centre. The centre is shaded by a canopy extended over head; above which the light is admitted from the top of the building. It produces a pleasing optical illusion, but it soon tired me.— From thence We went to see the Historic Gallery. being a collection of Paintings, for a very superb History of England now publishing; but they are neither so numerous nor so well executed, as those of the Shakespear Gallery.— Opie quite unequal to my expectations.— Evening with Frazier at the London Coffee house— Mr: Cutting.

5. Writing in the morning. Dined with Mr: Boylston, at the crown and anchor. a club party.— Saw there Mr: Parker.— Mr: Nicholls of whom Mr: Boylston speaks highly but with whom I had no opportunity for conversation— Evening at home reading.

6. Visit this morning from Mr: Copley. Was to have dined with Mr: Bell at Black-Heath. But an Engagement occurr’d which prevented me. Evening at Mr: Church’s. Twelfth Night. The amusements customary here on such occasions. Of the company I knew only Mrs: Johnson and her daughters, and Mr: Deas.— Cards and a little music.

7. Card from Lord Grenville informing me that the Princess of Wales was this morning brought to bed of a daughter.— Dined at Mr: Johnson’s. Company. Evening & supper there. Music. A young french Lady, performed very prettily upon the harp.
8. Dined at Mr: Vaughan’s at Hackney. Mr: W. Vaughan came into town with me. Mr: Deas there: and several Englishmen, whom I did not know.— Late Home.

9. Mr: Hallowell. Told me Mr: Pinckney had arrived. Went to his house; found it was a mistake. Mr: Cottrell. Told me that to-morrow would be the last day, for making enquiries at Carlton house.— This eternal round of forms!— Mr: W. Hope. All these people have so much civility, so much friendship in appearance, that their real dispositions are perceptible only by accident.— Dined at the Piazza Coffee-house. Mr: Morris— He was quite cool.— So much I expected. Evening at Mr: Johnson’s. Music on the Piano forte— Letters from America.

10. Visit from Mr: Phelps, arrived in Scott from America.— At Carlton House, to make the formal enquiries. Lady Cholmondely, was in waiting. Answered the Princess was as wellas could be expected, and the infant perfectly well. The hours are from two to four, and the names are taken down, of all the persons who go.— Dined at Mr: Hallowell’s and there in the Evening. Dissatisfied again. I can never please myself but in solitude. At least, I find it so in England.
11. Walking in the forenoon. Health very indifferent. Visits in the forenoon morning. Called on Mr: West, he was out of Town. Evening at Mr: Copley’s.— Mr: Erving.
12. President’s speech at the opening of Congress in the Papers. Evening at Mr: Johnson’s. Playing Boston. Was very fortunate. Captain H. Johnson going to France.

13. Attended the Levee— Saw Mr: Morris there. Heard of Mr: Pinckney’s arrival.— Mr: Hammond at the Levee too. The King did not speak to me. My reception at Court this day contrasted completely with those on former occasions, when I was to be cajoled into compliance. I valued it much more highly; it flattered my pride as much as the former fawning malice humbled it.— Dined at Mr: Hope’s. Company not very numerous. Evening at home.

14. Morning Papers, say that I took leave of the king at the Levee yesterday; introduced by Lord Grenville, and that I am upon my return home. I suppose it is meant as a hint to me to go away. I can certainly henceforth do no good here— But I cannot well go, without receiving further orders from home.— Dined at Mr: Copley’s and there late this Evening. Went with Foster to Mr: Johnson’s.

15. Called to see Mr: Pinckney, who arrived in town yesterday. Some conversation with him. Dined with Mr: Morris.— Messrs: Hope’s. A.M. Irujo who goes as Spanish Minister to America— Talk with Mr: Williams Hope.— Evening at home.
16. Dined with Mr: Erving. Company small. But large enough for me to talk more than enough. Evening at Mr: Johnson’s. Found Foster there, and other company.
17. Visit to Mr: Alexander. Dined at Mr: Johnson’s. Evening there as usual. Even there too I can only learn how much wiser I should be to stay at home.

18. Queen’s birth-day celebrated. Walk with Frazier in the morning to Mr: Pinckney’s. Crafts & Gardner have arrived and are stopp’d at Dover.— Frazier dined with me. Foster— We all walk’d in the Evening to see the illuminations which were small and then Supp’d with Frazier at the London Coffee House.— Home unwell.— Excused myself from attendance at the Drawing Room, and from dining with Lord Grenville.
19. Dined at Mr: Bromfield’s. Mr: Copley & his family. Mr: West &c. there. Evening at Mr: Johnson’s.— Some good music.
20. Quite unwell.— Dined with Frazier however. Crafts, Gardner, Deblois and several other Americans there. Walk in the evening with Gardner.
21. My health still declining. Dined at Mr: Hope’s in a family party— Sir Francis Baring there. Evening at Mr: Johnson’s. Late before I got there.
22. Dined at Mr: Bird’s. Mr: W. Vaughan. Mr: Bayard. Evening again at Mr Johnson’s. playing Boston. remarkably lucky. My walking repeatedly noticed, coming home.

23. Very unwell. have been many days incapable of any activity or exertion. Of course have done nothing. Paid some visits in the morning, but could not walk. Frazier, Crafts, Gardner and Forbes dined with me.— Suffering very severely. Relieved a little however this night.

24. Still unwell, but not so much as for some days past. Dined at Sir Francis Baring’s. Mr: Hope there. Sir John Dick came in after dinner. He appeared to me, very good for stage representation. Evening at Mr: Johnson’s.
25. Better in my health— Dined at Doctor Bancroft’s. Mr: Johnson and the Ladies there. After returning in the Evening, read the Triumphs of Temper.— Hardly enough above mediocrity.

26. Quite unwell again. Passed a sleepless night. Spent an hour or two with Crafts and Gardner at their lodgings. Dined with Mr: W. Vaughan. Went too late. Mr: Longley, Recorder of Rochester, Mr: Goring an Englishman, delicate as they generally are, were there: and also Mr: Bird. We went in the Evening to Drury Lane Theatre; found Miss Farren speaking the epilogue to a new play The Man of ten thousand. After which we had a Pantomimé. Harlequin Captive or the Magic Fire. Very well in point of Scenery: and the Pantomimes have nothing else.

27. At length made out to write a little. Dined with Mr: J. Taylor. Too much talk as usual. Evening at Mr: Johnson’s. Ball again for his daughter Louisa’s birth day. She is to be 21. on the 12th: of next Month. The party this Evening, to have the Company of some friends who will then be absent. Evening very agreeable. Danced with Miss Church, with Louisa &c.— After three in the morning before we retired.— Went home with the Miss Bancrofts.— Abed at about 5.
28. Up early. Dined at Mr: Boylston’s, and pass’d the Evening there. Home after 2. in the morning. Mr: Hallowell and his daughter. Mr: Nicholls, and other company there.
29. Walk with Crafts, and Gardner. Dined at Mr: Murdoch’s, with a company of Gentlemen. Evening at Mr: Johnson’s. Play’d cards— Stay’d a great deal too late. almost 2. A.M. before I came home

30. Visit from Mr: Copley.— Called on Crafts. Dined at Mr: Johnson’s, and Evening there, but not quite so late as yesterday. Called at the London Coffee House, and was with Frazier Crafts and Gardner till after 1. Report made by Crafts, to which attention must be paid. That report must speedily cease.
31. Dined at home— Most of the forenoon with Crafts and Gardner. Evening at Mr Johnson’s. Music. Not in the best temper.— Revolution.
